Award.AwardTitle: Additive Manufacturing of Controlled Anisotropic Materials via Electrically Assisted Nanocomposite Fabrication

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing (AM) has emerged as a promising rapid manufacturing approach for a wide variety of industries. Current AM processes can fabricate a model with good control on its shape but not on its material properties. Most AM processes only enable the fabrication of structures with isotropic material properties (they are the same in all directions). This award supports fundamental research on a novel additive manufacturing process that can accurately create anisotropic material properties (properties that vary with direction). This is accomplished in a three-dimensional (3D) structure by dynamically controlling electric fields while fabricating each layer, which has the result of orienting the short fiber reinforcement (in the form of carbon nanotubes or metal flakes) in the polymer. The shape is achieved by changing the projection image for each layer. Hence, varying material properties can be achieved in the fabricated structure even when using a single type of nanocomposite. The research results will significantly expand the capability of AM processes to fabricate anisotropic materials with enhanced structural, thermal, and electric properties. Such capability will enable novel design and fabrication of impact resistant nanocomposites, thermo-metamaterials, and wearable sensors. The new manufacturing process will provide US companies with a competitive edge and can lead to innovations in aerospace, consumer electronics, defense, and medical industries. The research outcomes will be integrated into undergraduate/graduate course development, as well as outreach programs to increase minority participation.

The research objective is to establish an electrically assisted mask-image-projection-based stereolithography (eMIP-SL) process that can build three-dimensional shapes using nanocomposites with controlled carbon nanotube (CNT) alignment for enhanced functional characteristics. Tasks on electrode design, nanocomposite preparation, CNT alignment control, and integration with projection-based stereolithography will be performed. The fundamental characteristic of the anisotropic mechanical/electrical/thermal properties of architectures with aligned carbon nanotubes will be studied including measuring the anisotropic mechanical properties, the electrical and thermal conductivities, and microstructure observation with optical/scanning electron microscopy. The fundamental mechanism for the anisotropic mechanical/electrical/thermal properties in the fabricated architectures will be studied as a function of the process parameters and resulting nano/microstructures. The research result will develop scientific and engineering knowledge on the eMIP-SL process for fabricating anisotropic multi-functional 3D structures using controlled properties of nanocomposites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to establish an electrically assisted mask-image-projection-based stereolithography (eMIP-SL) process that can control the anisotropic material properties of nanocomposites in the built structures for enhanced functional characteristics. Nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and Graphene nanoplatelet (GN) possess excellent mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties due to their unique structures. Polymer-based nanocomposites using such multifunctional nanofillers have great potential as next-generation structural materials. The eMIP-SL process developed in this research project offers the manufacturing ability to three-dimensional (3D) print structures with complex geometry and controlled nanofillers' orientations to achieve superior functional properties. A total of nine journal papers have been disseminated to the manufacturing and material research communities.

A number of significant results on the eMIP-SL process for nanocomposite manufacturing were found throughout this research. First, a bottom-up projection-based stereolithography process integrated with a controlled electric field and a rotation stage was developed to accurately align one-dimensional (1D) nanomaterials such as CNTs in a two-dimensional (2D) layer (Figure 1). Through dynamically controlling the electric field to align CNTs in each layer, Bouligand-type anisotropy inspired by the claws of crab and lobster was achieved in 3D-printed structures (Figure 2), enabling a new class of strong and lightweight composites. The Bouligand structure of aligned nanofibers can significantly enhance the impact resistance by 2-3 times. Second, the eMIP-SL process was used to build structures with controlled alignments of 2D nanosheets such as GN (Figure 3). The hierarchical 'brick and mortar' architecture inspired by nacres was built using eMIP-SL, showing similar toughness as the natural nacre (Figure 4). Third, the 3D-printed nacre structure has enhanced electrical properties for self-sensing capability (Figure 5). The 3D-printed meniscus with highly oriented nanofibers shows enhanced tensile modulus and fracture energy while keeping load bearing and shock absorption capability, presenting a customization solution to replace broken meniscus to a specific patient (Figure 6). The project demonstrated the eMIP-SL process to be versatile for both 1D and 2D nanomaterials and able to fabricate multiscale structures with enhanced mechanical, electrical, and biomedical properties.

The broader impacts of this project are shown through the opportunities provided to undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctors. Through funding for this work, a post-doctor became a faculty member who continues the line of the research work with his future students. A graduate student completed his Ph.D. dissertation within the grant period. Several undergraduate and master students conducted research under this grant and gained hands-on experience with additive manufacturing machines and laboratory equipment. The constructed prototype additive manufacturing system was also used in the demonstration to industrial visitors and high school students in various outreach programs over the grant period.

Inspired by eMIP-SL, the rotate blade casting-assisted and magnetic-field-assisted MIP-SL processes to achieve anisotropic material properties were developed by the PI for other nanocomposite materials, including boron nitride nanoplatelets and iron oxide nanoparticles. The 3D-printed structures with aligned boron nitride nanoplatelets showed enhanced thermal conductivity and heat dissipation, which are important for fire-retardant and mechanical protectivity applications. The 3D-printed structures with aligned iron oxide nanoparticles into microbundles showed enhanced compression performance. Working with our collaborators in medical school, we tested the 3D-printed painless microneedle patches for drug delivery during long-term wear, opening an avenue for future painless drug delivery in clinical trials.

Modified by: Yong Chen

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this research is to establish an electrically assisted mask-image-projection-based stereolithography (eMIP-SL) process that can control the anisotropic material properties of nanocomposites in the built structures for enhanced functional characteristics. Nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and Graphene nanoplatelet (GN) possess excellent mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties due to their unique structures. Polymer-based nanocomposites using such multifunctional nanofillers have great potential as next-generation structural materials. The eMIP-SL process developed in this research project offers the manufacturing ability to three-dimensional (3D) print structures with complex geometry and controlled nanofillers' orientations to achieve superior functional properties. A total of nine journal papers have been disseminated to the manufacturing and material research communities. A number of significant results on the eMIP-SL process for nanocomposite manufacturing were found throughout this research. First, a bottom-up projection-based stereolithography process integrated with a controlled electric field and a rotation stage was developed to accurately align one-dimensional (1D) nanomaterials such as CNTs in a two-dimensional (2D) layer (Figure 1). Through dynamically controlling the electric field to align CNTs in each layer, Bouligand-type anisotropy inspired by the claws of crab and lobster was achieved in 3D-printed structures (Figure 2), enabling a new class of strong and lightweight composites. The Bouligand structure of aligned nanofibers can significantly enhance the impact resistance by 2-3 times. Second, the eMIP-SL process was used to build structures with controlled alignments of 2D nanosheets such as GN (Figure 3). The hierarchical 'brick and mortar' architecture inspired by nacres was built using eMIP-SL, showing similar toughness as the natural nacre (Figure 4). Third, the 3D-printed nacre structure has enhanced electrical properties for self-sensing capability (Figure 5). The 3D-printed meniscus with highly oriented nanofibers shows enhanced tensile modulus and fracture energy while keeping load bearing and shock absorption capability, presenting a customization solution to replace broken meniscus to a specific patient (Figure 6). The project demonstrated the eMIP-SL process to be versatile for both 1D and 2D nanomaterials and able to fabricate multiscale structures with enhanced mechanical, electrical, and biomedical properties. The broader impacts of this project are shown through the opportunities provided to undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctors. Through funding for this work, a post-doctor became a faculty member who continues the line of the research work with his future students. A graduate student completed his Ph.D. dissertation within the grant period. Several undergraduate and master students conducted research under this grant and gained hands-on experience with additive manufacturing machines and laboratory equipment. The constructed prototype additive manufacturing system was also used in the demonstration to industrial visitors and high school students in various outreach programs over the grant period. Inspired by eMIP-SL, the rotate blade casting-assisted and magnetic-field-assisted MIP-SL processes to achieve anisotropic material properties were developed by the PI for other nanocomposite materials, including boron nitride nanoplatelets and iron oxide nanoparticles. The 3D-printed structures with aligned boron nitride nanoplatelets showed enhanced thermal conductivity and heat dissipation, which are important for fire-retardant and mechanical protectivity applications. Working with our collaborators in medical school, we tested the 3D-printed painless microneedle patches for drug delivery during long-term wear, opening an avenue for future painless drug delivery in clinical trials.
